choices.text: Tuberculoid leprosy with Antigen test positive
Tuberculoid leprosy with Antigen test negative
Lepromatous leprosy with positive antigen test
Borderline leprosy with negative antigen test

questions.text: A patient presented with a single skin lesion on arm with loss sensation and ulnar nerve enlargement. Histopathology shown below. What is the diagnosis and antigen test status?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Tuberculoid leprosy is characterized by strong cell-mediated immunity, localized lesions, nerve involvement, and a positive lepromin (antigen) test.

Histopathology reveals granulomas with well-formed epithelioid cells and Langhans giant cells, with no visible acid-fast bacilli.

Tuberculoid Leprosy (TT)

  • Tuberculoid leprosy (TT) is part of the Ridley-Jopling classification of Hansen's disease.
  • It reflects a strong immune response to Mycobacterium leprae
  • It is characterized by:
    • Asymmetric nerve involvement (e.g., ulnar thickening)
  • Histology: Well-formed granulomas with epithelioid cells and Langhans giant cells
  • Clinical features:
    • Few well-demarcated hypopigmented or erythematous plaques
    • Loss of sensation over lesions
    • Nerve thickening (e.g., ulnar, common peroneal)
    • Paucibacillary (very few or no bacilli seen on skin smear)
  • Histopathology:
    • Well-formed granulomas
    • Epithelioid cells, Langhans giant cells
    • Dense lymphocytic infiltrate
    • No acid-fast bacilli (AFB)
  • Lepromin test: Positive (due to good T-cell immunity)
  • Lepromin Test Overview
    • It is a skin test for measuring cell-mediated immunity to Mycobacterium leprae.
    • Positive in tuberculoid and borderline tuberculoid forms.
    • Negative in lepromatous and borderline lepromatous forms.

questions.text: A patient presents with a generalized rash over the body, a greyish patch over the anal area, and characteristic hair changes as shown in the image. Which of the following is the most likely causative organism?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The clinical triad of generalized rash, perianal condyloma lata, and moth-eaten alopecia is characteristic of secondary syphilis caused by Treponema pallidum.

  • Secondary syphilis, caused by the spirochete Treponema pallidum, typically occurs 6-12 weeks after the primary chancre heals.
  • It is characterized by systemic dissemination of the organism and presents with:
    • Generalized symmetrical maculopapular rash, often involving the palms and soles.
    • Condyloma lata - greyish, flat moist papules commonly seen in the perianal and genital region.
    • Moth-eaten alopecia - a patchy, non-scarring hair loss seen on the scalp.
  • These findings, especially when seen together, are highly suggestive of secondary syphilis.
  • Diagnosis is confirmed by serologic tests (e.g., VDRL/RPR and TPHA/FTA-ABS).
  • Treatment involves intramuscular benzathine penicillin G, which is the drug of choice.

Explanation of other options:

Staphylococcus aureus (Option A): Typically causes pustular or abscess-forming skin lesions like impetigo or folliculitis; it does not cause systemic rash with alopecia or perianal lesions as seen in syphilis.

Malassezia furfur (Option C): Causes pityriasis versicolor, which presents with hypopigmented or hyperpigmented macules, not generalized rash or hair loss.

Microsporum canis (Option D): A dermatophyte that causes tinea capitis with patchy scalp hair loss, but it does not cause perianal lesions or generalized body rash.

questions.text: A child presents with photosensitivity and multiple skin cancers. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Xeroderma pigmentosum is a rare genetic disorder characterized by defective DNA repair leading to photosensitivity and early-onset skin cancers.

  • Xeroderma pigmentosum (XP) is an autosomal recessive disorder caused by a defect in nucleotide excision repair mechanisms, specifically the inability to repair UV-induced thymidine dimers in DNA.
  • Clinical features include:
    • Severe sunburn with minimal UV exposure
    • Photosensitivity
    • Freckling and hyperpigmented macules in sun-exposed areas
    • Development of multiple skin malignancies (basal cell carcinoma, squamous cell carcinoma, and melanoma) at an early age
    • Ocular involvement and neurological degeneration in some cases
  • The hallmark is early and multiple cutaneous malignancies, especially in sun-exposed regions.

Explanation of other options:

Osteogenesis imperfecta (Option B): A genetic disorder of collagen type I causing bone fragility, blue sclerae, and fractures. Photosensitivity or skin cancer is not a feature.

Hypervitaminosis A (Option C): Causes dry skin, alopecia, hepatosplenomegaly, and pseudotumor cerebri, but not skin cancer or DNA repair defects.

Paget’s disease (Option D): A disorder of abnormal bone remodeling, usually in elderly individuals. It does not affect children or cause skin cancers.

questions.text: A sexually active patient presents with painful lesions on the penis
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Herpes genitalis presents as painful grouped vesicles or ulcers on an erythematous base, commonly caused by HSV-2.

  • Herpes genitalis is a sexually transmitted infection (STI) most often caused by Herpes Simplex Virus type 2 (HSV-2) and occasionally by HSV-1.
  • It is the most common cause of painful genital ulcers.
  • Clinical Features:
    • Painful vesicles or ulcers on the genitalia
    • Vesicles rupture to form shallow, painful ulcers with an erythematous base
    • Often associated with fever, dysuria, inguinal lymphadenopathy in primary infection
    • Lesions may recur due to latency in dorsal root ganglia
    • Diagnosis: Tzanck smear (shows multinucleated giant cells), PCR, viral culture, or serology

Explanation of other options:

Chancroid (Option B): Caused by Haemophilus ducreyi; presents with painful ulcers but these are deep, soft, non-indurated, often with ragged edges and painful inguinal lymphadenopathy (buboes), usually unilateral.

Syphilis (Options C): Caused by Treponema pallidum; primary chancre is painless, indurated, and clean-based. Also associated with painless lymphadenopathy.

Lymphogranuloma venereum (LGV)(Option D): Caused by Chlamydia trachomatis (serovars L1-L3); painless transient genital ulcer followed by painful inguinal lymphadenopathy (buboes) weeks later.

questions.text: A farmer presents with foot swelling and discharging sinuses. Staining of the lesion shows Gram-positive filamentous structures.
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Nocardia brasiliensis causes actinomycetoma, presenting with swelling, sinuses, and granules, and appears as Gram-positive filamentous bacteria on stains.

  • Nocardia brasiliensis is a soil-dwelling aerobic actinomycete, commonly causing actinomycetoma; a chronic, granulomatous infection of the skin and subcutaneous tissue. Farmers and those who walk barefoot are at higher risk.
  • Key clinical features of actinomycetoma include:
    • Painless swelling of the foot
    • Multiple discharging sinuses
    • Presence of sulphur granules (actually colonies of the bacteria)
    • Gram-positive, filamentous, weakly acid-fast rods on microscopy
    • Common in tropical/subtropical regions
  • Diagnosis is confirmed by Gram stain, acid-fast staining, culture, and biopsy.
  • Treatment includes trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole (TMP-SMX) and prolonged antibiotics.

Explanation of other options:

Sporothrix schenckii (Option B): A dimorphic fungus causing sporotrichosis, typically follows a thorn prick and causes nodular lymphangitis, not discharging sinuses with filamentous Gram-positive organisms.

Staphylococcus aureus (Option C): Causes acute pyogenic infections, abscesses, or cellulitis. It is Gram-positive cocci in clusters, not filamentous organisms, and doesn't cause actinomycetoma.

Aspergillus (Option D): A septate hyaline fungus causing aspergillosis, especially in immunocompromised hosts. It is not Gram-positive and does not appear filamentous on Gram stain.

questions.text: A sexually active woman presents with foul-smelling, watery vaginal discharge. What is the most likely causative organism?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Trichomonas vaginalis infection typically causes foul-smelling, thin, watery vaginal discharge, often accompanied by vulvar irritation and itching.

  • Trichomoniasis is a sexually transmitted infection caused by the protozoan parasite Trichomonas vaginalis.
  • It is one of the most common causes of malodorous, frothy, yellow-green vaginal discharge in women.
  • Key clinical features include:
    • Thin, foul-smelling, watery or frothy discharge
    • Strawberry cervix (punctate hemorrhages on cervix)
    • Vaginal pruritus and irritation
    • Dyspareunia and dysuria may also be present
  • Diagnosis:
    • Wet mount microscopy: Motile, flagellated protozoa
    • NAAT (nucleic acid amplification test) is highly sensitive
    • Vaginal pH typically > 4.5
  • Treatment:
    • Metronidazole (2g single dose or 500 mg BID x 7 days)
    • Treat sexual partners simultaneously to prevent reinfection

Explanation of other options:

Gardnerella vaginalis (Option A): Causes bacterial vaginosis, which presents with thin, grey-white discharge with fishy odor (especially after intercourse). Discharge is usually not watery or frothy, and clue cells are seen on microscopy.

Candida albicans (Option B): Causes thick, white, curd-like (cottage cheese) discharge, with intense itching. The discharge is typically odorless, not foul-smelling.

Lactobacillus (Option D): This is part of the normal vaginal flora and plays a protective role by maintaining acidic pH. It is not a pathogen.
